summary: This is a transcript from the Ghislaine Maxwell criminal trial jury selection process in the Southern District of New York on November 29, 2021. The document details the final stages of voir dire, including juror challenges, discussions about juror hardships (financial and travel conflicts), and the eventual seating of 18 jurors (12 regular and 6 alternates).

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal trial for which the jury is being selected.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: Presiding judge over the jury selection and trial proceedings.

persons.name: Damian Williams
persons.context: United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York, representing the prosecution.

persons.name: Haddon Morgan
persons.context: Prosecutor for the government in the case.

persons.name: Jeffrey S. Pagliuca
persons.context: Attorney for defendant Ghislaine Maxwell, participating in jury selection and peremptory challenges.

persons.name: Christian R. Everdell
persons.context: Attorney for defendant Ghislaine Maxwell, present during jury selection.

persons.name: Laura A. Menninger
persons.context: Attorney for defendant Ghislaine Maxwell, present during jury selection.

persons.name: Bobbi C. Sternheim

persons.name: Renato Stabile
persons.context: Attorney for defendant Ghislaine Maxwell, present during proceedings.

persons.name: Ann Lundberg

persons.name: Rohrbach

events.title: Jury Selection Finalization
events.description: The final step of selecting a jury for the Ghislaine Maxwell trial, involving voir dire questions, peremptory challenges, and resolution of juror hardships.

events.title: Juror Financial Hardship Resolution
events.description: Judge Nathan contacts a juror's employer to request an exception to company policy, successfully securing six weeks of paid leave so the juror can serve without financial hardship.

events.title: Juror Travel Conflict
events.description: A seated juror (Juror 58) reveals a surprise trip planned from December 24-28, creating a scheduling conflict with the trial. The juror is instructed to try to move the trip.

events.title: Juror Dismissal for Discussing Case
events.description: Juror 87 is dismissed for cause after disclosing they discussed the case with coworkers despite instructions not to.

locations: United States District Court Southern District of New York
keyFacts: The jury for the Ghislaine Maxwell trial was finalized on November 29, 2021, consisting of 12 regular jurors and 6 alternates.

Judge Alison J. Nathan personally intervened to contact a juror's employer, successfully securing an exception to company policy to provide six weeks of paid jury duty leave, preventing a financial hardship dismissal.
Several potential jurors were dismissed during the process, including one who discussed the case with coworkers and others due to peremptory challenges.
The document reveals logistical challenges of the high-profile trial, including the use of overflow courtrooms for jurors and live audio/video feeds.
The prosecution estimated a 25-minute opening statement, while the defense estimated under an hour.
